awd_titl_txt: CC* Networking Infrastructure: Jackson State University (JSU)-Research Network
awd_abstract_narration:
This project provides Jackson State University (JSU) researchers with a campus cyber infrastructure (CI) capability allowing expansion of big data and other network intensive collaborative research that depend on high-speed network access to local, regional, cloud and national compute and storage resources.  The project increases research network capacity to 100G, re-architects the campus research network, and strategic relocation of equipment to utilize a Science DMZ (Demilitarized zone - i.e., free from firewalls and other friction devices).  The research network includes centrally pooled High-Performance/Throughput Computing (HPC/HTC) resources designed to meet immediate and future research needs.  An increased focus on domain scientist talent is possible due to management and monitoring of the CI assets by a centralized, well-trained enterprise information technology team. This project enhances the end-to-end network services for researchers and is an important catalyst for the growing campus-wide interdisciplinary data science program. 

Application-specific network and computational needs for big data analytics, visualization, nanotoxicity, complex network analysis, science drivers and education are addressed.  Faculty, students, and the IT staff on campus and across campuses are engaged to leverage the new environment for their research, education, and operational needs. The project is disseminated through outreach workshop activities with Historical Black Colleges and Universities and other universities or the community college systems within the state of Mississippi who may be planning similar campus network upgrades.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Final Report Outcomes Summary

NSF Grant #1827098 ($500,000): CC* Networking Infrastructure: Jackson State University (JSU)-Research Network 2018-2021 PI (Deborah F. Dent) Co-PIs (Tor A Kwembe, Hung-Chung Huang, and Natarajan Meghanathan).

The focus of this project is to provide Jackson State University (JSU) researchers with a campus cyberinfrastructure (CI) capability allowing expansion of big data and other network-intensive collaborative research that depend on high-speed network access to local, regional, cloud, and national compute and storage resources. 

The broader impact includes:1) increased research network capacity to 100G, and 2) re-architected the campus research network and strategic relocation of equipment to utilize a Science DMZ (Demilitarized zone ? i.e., free from firewalls and other friction devices).  The research network is pooling resources designed to meet immediate and future research needs.  As a result, an increased focus on domain scientist talent is now possible due to managing and monitoring the CI assets by a centralized, well-trained enterprise information technology team. This project enhances the end-to-end network services for researchers and is an essential catalyst for the growing campus-wide interdisciplinary data science program.

Intellectual Merit:  Faculty, undergraduate, and graduate students can engage in research with Cloud computing to stimulate and promote a range of foundational, applied, and experimental research across many areas of cloud computing. The upgrades allow our faculty/students, who formally had connectivity with spatially distributed research teams working on various projects with varying computational challenges, to expand research capabilities. The PI, Co-PIs, and applications leaders have increased engagement in national and international intellectual conversations regarding the science drivers in part and to disseminate research outcomes published in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings.

Broader Impacts: The network upgrade and capability expansion has impacted the following areas: science discovery and curricula advancement, infrastructure, technology transfer, and workforce training.

 


Last Modified: 05/23/2022
Modified by: Tor A Kwembe
